accussed_details.name: Qadir Bakhsh
allegation: Murder of Ata Muhammad and Ghulam Muhammad

accussed_details.name: Amir Bakhsh
allegation: Murder of Ata Muhammad and Ghulam Muhammad

complaint_summary: On July 15, 1949, goats owned by Qadir Bakhsh trespassed into a field leased by Zar Ali Khan. The deceased, servants of Asmatullah Khan, attempted to impound the goats, leading to a fight where the deceased were killed by kulhari blows.
investigation_summary: Police prepared injury statements and inquest reports. Weapons used in the crime were recovered. Post-mortem confirmed death due to head injuries.
judgment_summary: The court found that the deceased acted illegally in seizing the goats. Qadir Bakhsh exercised his right of private defense but exceeded its limits. His conviction under Section 302 IPC was set aside, and he was convicted under Section 304(2) IPC with an 8-year rigorous imprisonment sentence.
punishment: 8 years rigorous imprisonment under Section 304(2) IPC.
Decision_or_verdict: Appeal rejected; conviction altered to Section 304(2) IPC.
legal_arguments: Right of private defense under Sections 97, 99, and 100 IPC.
Illegal seizure under Section 10 of the Cattle Trespass Act.

witness_statement.Ghulam Rasool: Left the scene to inform Asmatullah Khan.
witness_statement.Mst. Ghulam Maryam: Provided contradictory testimony but claimed to witness the fight.

legal_terms.Private Defense: Right to protect one's body and property within legal limits.
legal_terms.Cattle Trespass: Unauthorized entry of cattle into cultivated land.

words_and_phrases.Kulhari: A sharp-edged weapon used in the crime.

summary_vector_notes: The case revolves around the murder of two individuals by Qadir Bakhsh, who claimed self-defense after an altercation over the illegal seizure of his goats. The court acknowledged the right of private defense but ruled that the accused exceeded its limits, altering the conviction to culpable homicide not amounting to murder under Section 304(2) IPC.

facts.dispute: Trespassing goats and seizure attempt by deceased leading to fight.

legal_issues.primary_defense: Right of private defense of person and property under Section 97 of Indian Penal Code.
legal_issues.prosecution_argument: Illegal seizure of goats by deceased was theft.
legal_issues.defense_argument: Accused acted in self-defense after being injured.

judgment.initial_conviction: Section 302 Indian Penal Code - Death Sentence
judgment.final_conviction: Section 304(2) Indian Penal Code - Culpable Homicide

evidence.medical_report: Incised wound on accused's left palm caused by sharp-edged weapon.

key_points: Deceased were justified in impounding goats under Section 10 of Cattle Trespass Act.
Seizure did not amount to theft as there was no dishonest intention.
Minor injury on accused's hand could have been self-inflicted.
